title: 108_hr4431
content: The Act may be cited as "One Church, One Child Act of 2004". The Congress finds a shortage of qualified foster and adoptive parents, with a decrease in foster parents despite an increase in children in foster care. The number of waiting children for adoption exceeds the number of adoptions, leading to a growing need for post-adoption support. One Church, One Child is a national foster care and adoption ministry established in 1980 in Chicago, Illinois. It aims to provide services for at-risk children and support adoptive families. Over 140,000 children have been placed in adoptive families through its programs. One Church, One Child has successfully placed over 140,000 children in adoptive families nationwide. Despite its success, programs based on this concept have received limited federal funding. The creation of a federally-funded grant program to support programs modeled on One Church, One Child will benefit abused and neglected children by increasing the pool of qualified adoptive and foster parents. SEC. 479B. ONE CHURCH, ONE CHILD GRANTS are being added to Part E of title IV of the Social Security Act to provide federal funding for programs modeled on One Church, One Child. This aims to increase the pool of adoptive and foster parents for abused and neglected children. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities to establish or expand programs that recruit and train foster and adoptive parents through networks of public, private, and faith-based organizations. Eligible entities include state or local governments, public agencies, nonprofit organizations, and private entities. A local public agency, community-based or nonprofit organization, or private entity can apply for funds to carry out programs for children through the Secretary. The application must include a project description with details on the number of children to be served and the services to be provided. The application for funds must include a description of services for prospective adoptive and foster parents, coordination efforts with state and local entities, and agreement to maintain records and reports. The agreement includes maintaining records, submitting reports, and cooperating with reviews and audits as required by the Secretary for oversight purposes. The term 'State' refers to various regions including the 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and others. The Secretary is authorized up to $20,000,000 annually from 2005 to 2009. Grant funds under this section are available for three years. The Secretary can redistribute unused grant funds among eligible entities in need. Religious organizations are considered equally for grant awards. The Secretary considers religious organizations equally for grant awards, as long as they comply with the Establishment Clause. Governments cannot discriminate against religious organizations participating in funded programs. Religious organizations cannot be forced to change their internal governance or remove religious art from their premises. Religious organizations must comply with the Establishment Clause to be eligible for grants or program participation. Funds provided to religious organizations cannot be used for sectarian worship, instruction, or proselytization. They are subject to the same regulations as other nongovernmental organizations for fiscal accountability. Religious organizations receiving funds must adhere to the same regulations as other nongovernmental organizations for fiscal accountability. They must keep the funds separate from other organization funds. SEC. 479C. National Clearinghouse for Adoption Promotion and Foster Parent Recruitment Programs; Annual Report to Congress. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to coordinate activities for recruiting foster and adoptive parents and providing support to foster families. The curr_chunk focuses on providing technical assistance, training, and collecting information on the effectiveness of programs for recruiting and supporting foster and adoptive parents. The curr_chunk focuses on assisting the Secretary in evaluating the effectiveness of foster and adoptive parent recruitment programs by collecting data and preparing reports. A nationally recognized, nonprofit organization is selected through a competitive process to support adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment efforts. The organization selected by the Secretary on a competitive basis must have experience in providing consultation and training to faith-based and community organizations interested in adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment. They should also have a national reputation in working with these organizations to recruit and train prospective foster and adoptive parents, as well as experience in establishing programs based on the One Church, One Child model. The Secretary must prepare annual reports to Congress detailing the number of entities receiving grants under section 479B and the number of foster parents and adoptive families recruited by the supported programs. Authorization of appropriations is limited to $1,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009. The Secretary must provide annual reports to Congress on the number of foster parents and adoptive families recruited by programs supported with grants, the number of children placed with them, and the outcomes of such placements, as well as any other relevant information for program evaluation.
